stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with acute kidney injury (AKI) secondary to dehydration. Which nursing interventions are essential for this patient's care? (Select all that apply. There may be zero, one, or more correct answers in each column.)

column2.text: Administer potassium supplements without checking potassium levels
Assess for signs of fluid overload

rationale.correct: Administer intravenous fluids; Monitor urine output; Assess for signs of fluid overload; Monitor electrolyte levels; Avoid nephrotoxic medications (e.g., NSAIDs).

mnemonic.name: AKI Care
mnemonic.description: Assess (vitals, labs, I&O), Keep hydrated (IV fluids), Identify (and avoid) nephrotoxins, Control (electrolytes).

rationale.incorrect: Restrict fluid intake (patient is dehydrated); Administer potassium supplements without checking potassium levels (patient is already hyperkalemic); Encourage a high-protein diet (can worsen AKI); Discontinue continuous cardiac monitoring (patient is unstable).

questionTrap.name: Fluid Restriction Temptation
questionTrap.description: Students may incorrectly assume fluid restriction is always appropriate for renal patients, failing to recognize the dehydration aspect in this specific case.

clinicalPearls: Early recognition and treatment of AKI are crucial to prevent progression to kidney failure.
Accurate fluid balance monitoring is essential in patients with AKI.
Hyperkalemia is a common and life-threatening complication of AKI.

itemContext.sbar: Patient admitted with AKI. Patient reports 3 days of nausea and vomiting, unable to tolerate PO fluids. Last void was yesterday. Currently hypotensive and tachycardic.

currentMedications: Hydrochlorothiazide (stopped 3 days ago due to nausea)
